text: one of the problems right now with all
the information around us is it allows
us to be very busy but busyness and
productivity they are not the same thing
they're actually very frequently at odds
with each other
so the most productive people they tend
to do things like only check their email
twice a day they tend to delete their
email much much more quickly and at
higher rates than everyone else there's
a guy named Jake Knapp actually Google
Ventures who has the latest Apple iPhone
and the only things he has on is the
ability to make phone calls and get text
messages it's essentially the most
expensive complicated clamshell phone on
earth because that way he can't just
distract himself when he's standing in
line or when he has a down moment
instead of just checking his email he
has to actually think until about the
1950s or 1960s efficiency and
productivity were somewhat synonymous
most of us would have gone to jobs where
we would have had a boss who tells us
what to do or clear marching orders and
so being busy and being productive would
have been one and the same but in
today's economy for this economic
revolution that we're living through
which most of economists agree is on par
at this point the agrarian revolution in
the industrial revolution efficiency and
productivity have become disconnected
you can spend your entire day in busy
and efficient right you can get through
every single email in your inbox you can
spend all of your time going to every
single meeting that shows up on your
calendar and you can get nothing
important done but the people who win
the ones who succeed
they're the ones who recognize that and
they carve out time during their day
even if it feels wasteful in small ways
to think more deeply to choose the right
tools to figure out how to sharpen their
focus to figure out how to make their
team come together really gel those are
the people who are perfect
those are the people who will succeed
